Compelling article, yet it hasn't changed my opinion on death with dignity.

I took a class from Professor Hopkins on Shakespeare at the University of Utah in 1983. I was supposed to fret over writing something insightful about a bi-polar Danish prince. Instead, I was distracted with helping care for and watch my generation of friends die from AIDS.

The efficiency and often pernicious ways which AIDS wiped us out motivated many of us to devise end-of-life-schemes and promise one another to put them immediately into action based upon "the drool factor." We saw what was happening to the young men in our community. The assault of strange infections with their lingering manifestations on what were once strong, young bodies haunted us and served as a constant topic of conversation."Please, if I ever get to the stage I'm helplessly soaking in my own drool, I've stashed enough drugs to put me to sleep." We then confided in those we trusted the location of a bottle or box of pills we hoped would ensure us a comfortable enduring sleep society usually reserves only for blind, incontinent poodles.

Somehow that pandemic overlooked me. Yet we helped many who begged us to help death kindly stop for them. We weren't concerned with laws or illegal acts. Certainly, our government didn't care and physicians were more than happy to scribble down "AIDS-related illness" as cause of death and move on.

For me the cruelest irony is to be stuck teaching Moby Dick at 72. Why not Colette?

Privately run day care centers or preschools are not required to admit children with special needs (an ADHD diagnosis is a special need). Public school districts however, are required to provide a "free and appropriate public education" for all children with special needs, from birth through age 21. If your child has ADHD, contact your school district - they may need to screen/evaluate him themselves, but they are required to find appropriate placement for him, which would include the therapeutic services he needs to be successful in kindergarten and beyond. That may involve a special education or therapeutic classroom, or may involve a general education classroom with a paraprofessional to provide your son extra support. Depending on the school district, there might not be full day childcare available, but there are legally mandated minimum educational services that the public school district is required to provide.

Check out this website to find out about your child's legal right to education services: http://www.dredf.org/idea/

Texas has three policies that work together to achieve a certain result. Although this result flows inevitably from these policies, their defenders lie to themselves and others about what these policies, working together, bring about.

The first policy is restricting the ability of young people to engage in sex without getting pregnant. This is done by restricting information, giving out false information, and promoting certain religiously-based values to the exclusion of others.

The second policy is to make it difficult or impossible to get abortions. particularly for people who lack the ability and means to go out of state. They are forced to bear the child whether or not they think they are economically or psychologically prepared for motherhood.

The third policy is to provide little medical or economic help to young women who get pregnant.

Added together, these policies serve the function of enforcing conservative Christian sexual morality by making it as probable as they can that women who violate this morality will have children they will have trouble supporting, and will suffer physical and mental pain and stress and regret that they broke God's commandments. This is rough on the kids, of course, but their God never let a little collateral damage deter the punishment of the wicked. After all, they had the pleasure and now must pay for it, etc..

And all of this in the name of loving and protecting the children and obeying God. Taliban, American style.

The argument that high IQ makes one deserving of wealth (especially inherited wealth) is ludicrous.

I think the argument, Susan, is that wealth shows that one has a high IQ and that one would not be wealthy is one were not intelligent.

Conversely, these specious arguments assert that poverty shows that one has a low IQ and that one would not be poor if one were intelligent.
Brilliant, informative comment. Thank you.

As Balzac noted, “Behind every great fortune there is a crime.” Nonetheless, those at the top always spin narratives to justify being at the top and staying there even if their advantage is based on a family history of slavery, conquest, colonialism, or the exploitation of workers. Even the offspring of a Mafia don believe they deserve to live in better style than those who have been paying protection money.

For the Victorians, their narrative held that the aristocracy was well bred and the lower classes needed to know their place and grotesque wealth differences were merited. For the ancient Romans the patricians had power over the plebeians based entirely on heredity and that system was ended only by a revolution that led to an Emperor. The caste system in India was based on religious inheritance of cleanliness and filth handed down over the generations. Always the difference is merited according to those on top.

Comments to today's article show a similar facility to spin a narrative justifying privilege--high IQ mothers have children with high IQ fathers to breed children who then merit keeping the family wealth. Lower class children are born into single-parent families, so they are bound to pay a price for the bad choices by their irresponsible parents. The narratives spun in these comments are no less self serving than those of the patrician Romans, the Brahman Indians, and the aristocratic Victorians, and the operative part of the phrase is "self serving."

Up now to page 40.  I suppose to understand this beautiful exposition one should know a bit about eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, i.e., a bit about matricies.  Not to mention a not-necessarily mathematical comprehension of the standard model of particle physics; there are many books about this written for the so-called intelligent layman.

SYMMETRY

Benson: I'm very glad you appreciate the book.

The most relevant Lie groups (named after the Norwegian Sophus Lie, who introduced them around 1900) are the simple Lie groups. Their full description (classification) is considered a triumph of the 20th century.

Physicists had a hard time accepting them, but now the standard model of particle physics is based on them.

I have introduced the quantum subgroups of the simple Lie groups, I showed that the simple Lie groups can be built out of the quantum subgroups of the first simple group, the spinors or SU(2).

I am now building by an extension of these methods the higher versions of these simple Lie groups.

Simple Lie groups give the data to build 1 space+1time dimensional quantum field theory.

The new, higher ones, which I am developing, will hopefully do the same for the physical 3 space+1 time dimensions.

A lot of this math is motivated by physics, and I also work as a physicist, both at home and abroad.

The NSF supported my project with one of the highest awards in mathematics.

So a couple of days ago I purchased a slim Dover reprint book, "Lie Groups for Pedestrians" by Harry J. Lipkin [who taught at the Weizmann Institute]. What a gem! After reading the IX pages of prefaces [first preface written in 1965; the second shortly thereafter] I was absolutely hooked and have so far savored every word and [easy] equation of the first 22 pages.

I'm a little unsure what 'pedestrian' in the title actually refers to but Dr. Lipkin certainly knows how to explain the role the symmetry in particle physics without committing to the theory of groups and all of its heavy apparatus. While I suppose this gem of a book might be heavy going for those with just two year's of high school algebra, but no more is actually required, at least so far.

The so-called standard theory of modern particle physics as moved beyond what this little book covers but if one just wants some appreciation of how-it-goes, that is available here. Incidentally, this is closely related to the sort of stuff Adrian O claims he does; one will note the topics and ideas bear little resemblance to the mathematics which is in aid of climatology. The only overlap would be in aiding the determination the outer electron orbitals of the atoms in tri-atomic atmospheric gases; I don't think this book treats that topic but it'll offer a starter for the advanced atmospheric physics books which do.

Recently blogs are filled with do-it-yourself actuaries who expect an instant underwriting death spiral.

There is robust health plan participation in the exchanges. Other states are reporting lower than expected premiums. This is not a plot. Participation and premiums are determined by the health plans (also known as market forces). While the lower premiums are political good news, they matter little to the exchanges since the subsidies derive from the member's income, not from the size of the premium. Since the subsidy grows if the premiums are higher, an underwriting death spiral is nearly impossible if enrollees are mostly subsidy eligible, which is what HHS expects and where it is marketing. Taking us back to why there is robust health plan participation.

You cite young healthy individuals who are not subsidy eligible who are expected to be vocal and unhappy due to increased premiums. I think they are figments of the GOP imagination in the first year or so. If they have employer-based insurance, they keep it. If they have low cost, medically underwritten, individual policies, they keep their current policies. If they don't have insurance and they want to avoid the penalty, they will still be able to buy medically underwritten individual policies if they qualify. This supposed group does not exist unless health plans exit the individual business. There are reasons that this may happen over time, but will not happen next year since it is currently very profitable.

End of life is complicated, especially when death comes very slowly for one partner and the other can't be sure whether or when she/he is wrongly mercifully "letting" the other die or selfishly "refusing" to let the other go.

Continuing a dialogue about the next step in race relations for America, writes Jada Smith relating to the Sunday shows.

Searching for the truth about who we are as Americans would be a good start. Surely President Obama has for the time he came upon the scene talked about America as being one...no blue or red states...no Black or White or in-between. (Obviously used as a political cliche to garner votes.)

There is no doubt that President Obama has good intentions in his many ways of tackling the problems that face us: yet for one to criticize President Obama, it becomes a racial issue.

Searching for the truth is a dialogue supposedly between many...not one man.

The struggles we face are multiplied, due to the lack of respect and tolerance for one another. It is not only racial...it is every conceivable human trait ever to be part of mankind from the very beginning. Some one will discriminate, no matter what. Laws may be made to stop discrimination, but will surely fail without leadership from the top.

Our notable pundits and politicians on the Sunday shows are right to talk the talk...they must also walk the walk.
